title: What are some interesting primary history books? - Quora

response.answer_text: By primary I assume that you mean generalized, and not primary source material? Here are a few of my favorites: “Maps of Time” - David Christian “A People's History of the World: From the Stone Age to the New Millennium” - Chris Marker “A People’s History of the United States” - Howard Zinn “Jerusalem: The Biography” - Simon Sebag Montefiore “Germany: Memories of a Nation” - Neil MacGregor “Ill Fares the Land” - Tony Judt “The Story of Civilization” - Will & Ariel Durant “The Battle for God: A History of Fundamentalism “ - Karen Armstrong That should get you started, but I could go on… or are you looking for primary sources, meaning first hand accounts? In that case, you’d need to be more specific as to what area that you are wanting to study, then I can help you… Oh, here’s a couple more fun ones: “The Hindus: An Alternative History” - Wendy Doniger “Ancient Persia: A Concise History of the Achaemenid Empire, 550–330 BCE” - Matt Waters “The Discovery of France” - Graham Robb “Civilization of the Middle Ages: Completely Revised and Expanded Edition” - Norman Cantor
